attributes.comment:
I am writing on behalf of the proposed increase in adoption related expenses
through CIS.
My husband and I currently have a dossier in China - log in date March 27, 2006.
Due to the slow down in the process on China's side all of our documents through
CIS will expire prior to our travel to China (potentially before we even get our
referral).
We are already having to pay for documents we already have had done -
fingerprints, home study, I-600A and 171-H. Too add insult to injury an increase
in 66% would make this process unreachable for many families.
With CCAA making many changes in their guidelines for who can adopt the
number of families will decline, add the increase in fees (and having to do them at
least twice in the process) will make international adoption out of reach for many
families.
At times it feels like international adoption fees through CIS are here to put fat in
the budget of CIS.
We are a military family. We understand homeland security issues and we
support regulations that keep our country safe. Putting American Citizen's safety
first on the priority list in fine - but increasing adoption fees to pay for CIS to do
their other jobs - not appropriate.
Our family did not choose international adoption first. We looked locally - through
foster/adoption options. We were told by one agency that since my husband
deploys we would never be able to adopt through them. We were told by the
Dept. of Social Service that if we wanted a baby we needed to look elsewhere.
When we looked into local adoptions through "unexpecting" expecting moms it
was like a baby market with the lawyers. Our family has even tried to do foster-
adopt in another state with a little girl who was Native American. We were shot
down there due to ICWA (Indian Child Welfare Act). Since we are not Native
American we could not adopt her - she is on her 15th family through foster care
now..
I will add one more detail that has frustrated me with CIS. Our local office in
Charlotte. When dealing with the appointment office we have had many
challenges. First, they sent our money order back in October 2005 because it
was too much. We redid the money order and sent it 5 days before a price
increase. I did signed return rec't. They held on to it for 7 days and then sent it
back so I could send more money. With a looming year long deployment on our
horizon I was beyond irritated. When I called the office to speak to a supervisor I
was treated like I was trying to do something illegal.
My husband recently came home from the deployment. Our fingerprints were
about to expire so I sent a letter explaining that we would need to renew our
prints. The challenge was making sure we got an appointment that was in
between all of the schools my husband is slated to attend before the next
deployment. I got my letter returned to me. I was told that they did not make
appointments based on things like that. I would have to send another letter in
later and hope I get an appointment that works.
Hey, thanks! Not like my husband is fighting for anything! I hate pulling the Army
card, but give me a break. I have no control over his deployment schedule and
what this county needs him to do. A bit of understanding and cooperation would
be helpful. We are not a sole case in this scenario in that office - there are quite a
few military families who look to international adoption here in North Carolina.
I would encourage all involved to look in other places when trying to increase a
budget. Adopting families are not the gravy train here.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By AnnMarie Adams
